You are a newborn and infant care specialist. My 6 month old daughter Zoe has been crying for an hour. It's 5 pm, she last ate at around 2pm. Last week she got her vaccinations. Based on this information what should I do to support her?

It's not uncommon for babies around Zoe's age to get fussy. Given that it's been three hours since her last feeding, I recommend offering her a bottle or breastfeed to see if she's hungry. 6 month olds typically need to eat every 3-4 hours. Additionally, considering she had her vaccinations last week, she might still be experiencing some discomfort, so some gentle cuddles and reassurance could help calm her down. You can also try checking her diaper to ensure she's not uncomfortable from a soiled diaper. If she continues to cry and you're unable to soothe her, it's always a good idea to consult with her pediatrician for further guidance.
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.

You are a newborn and infant care specialist. My 18 month old son Brian has been crying in a low-pitched cry for 10 minutes. It's 5 pm, he last ate at around 10am. He’s also been sucking his tongue, putting his fingers into his mouth, and lip-smacking. Based on this information what should I do to support him?

​​Brian's low-pitched cry, sucking his tongue, putting his fingers into his mouth, and lip-smacking are all classic self-soothing behaviors that indicate he might be hungry. Given that he's been crying for 10 minutes, it's likely that he's trying to self-soothe as well. I recommend offering him a snack or a drink to see if he's hungry or thirsty. If these strategies don't seem to work, it's always a good idea to consult with his pediatrician to rule out any underlying medical issues.
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.
My 20 month son has been crying a whiny, nasal, continuous cry that builds in intensity. It is the morning and he slept well last night. Why is he crying?
A whiny, nasal, continuous cry is usually a baby's signal that he’s uncomfortable. Have you changed his diaper? That may be a possible reason.
I tried what you recommended but that didn’t seem to work. What else should I try?
I’m sorry that didn’t work. Other possible causes are that your baby is hungry, hot or cold, or wants to be held. Hopefully that helps!
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.
My 4 week old baby is crying intensely and screaming. She’s also fidgeting. It’s been a few hours already, starting in the late afternoon.

The solution: Your baby almost certainly has colic. Colic peaks around 3 weeks of age, and these are the exact symptoms of colic. While it's difficult to calm a colicky baby, you can try comforting positions (laying her on her tummy on your forearm or across your knees, supporting her head and rubbing her back). You can also try putting her down on her back and gently pushing her knees up to her stomach for 10 seconds, then releasing and repeating, in hopes of getting the gas out of her.

My 4 month old is crying in the grocery store and I don’t know what to do! We’re receiving a lot of unwanted information and I know the grocery store is pretty cold, so that might be why. What can I do?

If your 4-month-old is crying in the grocery store, try checking if they’re cold and cover them with a blanket or jacket if needed. Offer a comforting toy or pacifier to soothe them. Ensure they’re fed and have a clean diaper, as hunger or discomfort might be the cause. Try holding or gently rocking them to calm them down. If possible, find a quiet spot to ease the overstimulation.

My 10 month daughter has been crying non-stop for a white now. I have been holding her but it doesn’t seem to work. What should I do?
Crying can be a late sign of hunger. If she is moving her hands to her mouth and smack her lips, then she probably wants to eat.
I tried to give her food but she is not eating. What else should I try?
I’m sorry that didn’t work. If your baby isn't hungry, offer a pacifier.
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.
My 6 month son has been crying intensively for since he woke up a few minutes ago. Why is he crying?
Hold your baby to your shoulder or chest. Crying babies may be soothed by gentle rubbing or pats on the back.
I tried what you recommended but that didn’t seem to work. What else should I try?

I’m sorry that didn’t work. Sometimes gentle rocking or a walk in a baby carrier can soothe a crying infant. You also could place your baby in an infant swing. Or take your baby for a car ride. The noise that the car engine makes might soothe your baby.
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.
My 4 month daughter has been crying the whole night and we can’t get her to fall asleep . Why is she crying?
In general, dress your baby in about as many layers of clothes as you're wearing. Add or remove a layer as needed.
I removed a layer of clothing but she is still crying. What else should I try?
I’m sorry that didn’t work. A wet or soiled diaper can cause tears. Check your baby's diaper often to make sure it's clean and dry
You are a newborn and infant care specialist.
My 2 month son has been crying the whole day and we can’t figure out what’s wrong . Why is he crying?

Most newborns eat every few hours around-the-clock. Crying can be a late sign of hunger. Look for early signs of hunger. For example, babies might move their hands to their mouths and smack their lips.
I gave him good but we didn’t want to eat. He is still crying! What else should I try?

I’m sorry that didn’t work. Some babies have frequent, long-lasting and intense crying known as colic. It often starts a few weeks after birth. But colic often gets better by the time a baby is 3 to 4 months old. You should check with a doctor.
